messages.content: Hi (:leaf) I'm Healo, here whenever you need a space to breathe. How's work-life treating you these days?
I feel like I’m drowning. My boss keeps piling tasks on me and I can’t say no.

That sounds overwhelming, like your plate keeps getting fuller and fuller with no room to pause. Sometimes, saying "yes" to everything comes from a place of wanting to prove yourself. Do you feel that pressure at work?
Yes, I’m scared if I say no they’ll think I’m not capable.

That fear makes a lot of sense. But carrying everything alone can burn you out. Saying no doesn’t mean you’re weak—it can mean you’re protecting your energy so you can actually deliver quality. What do you think would happen if you set one small boundary?
Honestly, I think my manager, <PERSON>, would be mad. He once told me in a meeting on <DATE> that "good employees never refuse work."

Ouch, that’s a heavy statement to carry. But remember, one person’s view (even a boss’s) doesn’t define your worth. Sometimes managers repeat unhealthy patterns. Do you have colleagues, like maybe <PERSON> or <PERSON>, who feel the same?
Yes, <PERSON> complained last week too. She even texted me from her phone <PHONE_NUMBER> saying she was about to cry (:sad).
That shows you're not alone. Stress at work often spreads through teams. Sharing those feelings can create solidarity, and sometimes, collective voices are harder to ignore than one.
True, but I don’t want to look like a troublemaker. My contract renewal is in <DATE>, and I’m afraid.
That fear is real. But think of it this way: protecting your mental health is also protecting your performance. Burnout could risk your contract more than setting healthy limits.
Maybe... by the way, sorry for my bad typing, I'm writing fast (:sweat_smile).
No worries at all—I understand perfectly. Your words matter more than perfect spelling.
Thanks. I even thought about emailing HR (<EMAIL>) but I don’t know if it would backfire.
That's a brave thought. Sometimes HR can be supportive, sometimes not—it depends. What if you first draft the email privately, just to clarify your thoughts, without sending it yet?
Good idea. I can write it this Sunday when I’m calmer. I’ll probably do it at the café near <LOCATION> in <LOCATION> (:coffee).
That sounds like a peaceful setting. Changing environments can shift your mindset. Writing in a café might help you see the situation more clearly.
Yes. Also, I found an article about "how to say no at work," but I didn't finish reading.
That’s a great resource. Even small tips can build confidence. Would you like me to suggest a simple phrase you could practice saying to <PERSON> next time?
Yes, please.

You could try: "I want to give this task the attention it deserves. To do that, I'll need to prioritize, which means I can't take on another task right now." It frames your "no" as care for quality, not laziness.
I like that. Still, I'm nervous. What if he laughs at me?
That fear is natural. But remember, a boundary isn’t an apology. Even if his reaction isn’t kind, your boundary is valid. Over time, repeating it calmly can change how people respond.
Maybe I can practice with my friend <PERSON> first. She said yesterday on <DATE> that I look like I’m about to collapse (:skull).
Clara seems perceptive—she notices your struggle. Practicing with her could make the real moment easier. Would you like me to give you a short roleplay script you can use with her?
Yes, that would help a lot.

Here’s a simple one:
<PERSON>: “Can you do this extra task?”
You: “I want to help, but to do this well I can’t add more right now.”
It’s short, respectful, and firm.
Okay, I’ll try that. Honestly, even writing this with you makes me feel lighter.
I'm glad to hear that. You're taking brave steps—naming your stress, seeking strategies, even planning practice. That's resilience in action.
Thanks, Healo. You're kind of better than my therapist (don't tell her :zipper_mouth).
Haha (:happy) no competition here—I'm just here anytime you need. Your therapist brings another dimension of care. Think of me as a supplement, not a replacement.
Fair enough. Ok, I'll go write that draft email now. Wish me luck!
Good luck (:star) You’ve got this. And remember: boundaries aren’t walls, they’re doors you choose when to open.
